TABREF132.text: Gulnara Aghayeva 1 Azerbaijan Medical University, Z.Adigezalov str.117, apt2, Baku, AzerbaijanBackground and aims: In chronic hepatitis C, insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes mellitus are more often seen than in healthy controls or chronic hepatitis B patients. The aim of the present study was to determine the relationship between insulin resistance (IR) or diabetes mellitus and SVR rates in patients with chronic hepatitis C. Methods: Between 2003 and 2008 a total 680 adult patients (55 patients with carbohydrates disorders-insulin resistance or diabetes mellitus) with chronic hepatitis C and 248 patients with chronic hepatitis B were evaluated. Overweight was defined as BMI [25 kg/m 2 , and IR as HOMA [2. Serum HCV RNA and genotype were determined for all patients. Fibrosis was evaluated using Metavir score. Severe fibrosis was F3-F4. Results: 82% of the patients were with genotype 1. Type 2 diabetes mellitus is more often seen in patients with CHC (8 vs. 2% in patients with CHB). Severe fibrosis and cirrhosis (F3-F4) among patients with diabetes mellitus and high IR (HOMA-IR[4)  were appeared in 53% cases. SVR in patients with low IR (HOMA-IR \4) was 63% (vs. 9% in patients with high HOMA-IR[ 4). SVR among chronic hepatitis C patients with diabetes mellitus was 27%. Lowest SVR (18%) was appeared in patients with BMI [30 kg/m 2 . Most of chronic hepatitis C patients with diabetes mellitus had BMI [25 kg/m 2 (85%). Conclusions: Insulin resistance emerges as the most important host factors in the prediction of response in non-diabetic patients treated with peginterferon plus ribavirin. Management of IR should become part of the assessment of chronic hepatitis C patients. Diabetes mellitus is a predictor of treatment failure in HCV patients treated with pegylated interferon plus ribavirin, especially in group of the patients with BMI [30 kg/m 2 .Estimation of Insulin Resistance in Patients with Hepatitis B and Hepatitis C Virus Related Chronic Liver DiseaseAkmat Ali 1 , Mamun Mahtab 1 , Salimur Rahman 1 , Mobin Khan 1Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujib Medical University, Dhaka, BangladeshBackground: Liver is the principal organ regulating carbohydrate metabolism. It is still unclear whether hepatitis B and hepatitis C virus are responsible for insulin resistance. The aims of the study was to evaluate if patients with HBV and HCV related chronic liver disease (CLD) develop insulin resistance (IR) * p-value \ 0.05 comparison of responders and non responders and to compare if there is any difference in the IR between these two groups of patients. Methods: 30 patients of HBV and 30 patients of HCV related CLD between 20 and 60 years were studied. They had no metabolic syndrome. Result: Mean age of HBV and HCV related chronic liver disease were 35.37 ± 10.04 and 42.33 ± 12.88 years respectively. Mean fasting serum insulin 7.06 ± 2.2 lU/ml in HBV related CLD and 9.08 ± 3.06 in HCV related CLD groups. The difference of mean fasting serum insulin was significant between the two groups (p = 0.013). The mean fasting serum glucose in HBV related CLD and in HCV related CLD groups were 4.37 ± .58 and 4.6 ± .59 mmol/L respectively (p = 0.781). The cutoff value of HOMA-IR was 1.73, mean HOMA-IR of HBV and HCV related chronic liver disease were 1.35 ± .44 and 1.89 ± .71 respectively (p = 0.001). The HOMA-IR value was significantly higher in HCV related CLD than those with HBV. Conclusion: HCV is likely to be independently associated with insulin resistance.Antioxidant and Immunomodulator Effect of Viusid Ò in Patients with Chronic Hepatitis C: A Double-blind, Placebo-Controlled Study Eduardo Vilar Gomez 1 , Yadina Martinez Perez 1 , Hector Vega Sanchez 1 , María de la Concepcion Abreu Vazquez 1 , Ali Yasells Garcia 1 , Enrique Arus Soler 1 , Luis Calzadilla Bertot 1

TABREF133.text: Interferon-2a Decreases Expression of TBC1D20, a Possible Cofactor Involved in the Replication of HCV in HepatocytesRong-Lin Zheng 1 , Yue-Xin Zhang 1 , Gang Li 2 Department of Infectious Diseases, First Affiliated Hospital, Xinjiang Medical University, Liyushan Road 1, Urumqi Xinjiang, 830054, China, 2 Third Hospital, Zhongshan University, Guangzhou, Guangdong ProvinceAims: TBC1D20, a Rab1 GTPase-activating Protein has recently been shown to interact with HCV NS5A, thus suggesting that it might involve in the replication of HCV. This study is to explore whether IFN combined with ribavirin can affect TBC1D20 expression in HepG2 and Huh7 cell lines. Methods: HepG2 and huhu7 cells were treated by various dose of interferon-2alpha (1-1,000 U/ml) and ribavirin (20-500 um/L). The mRNA levels of TBC1D20 in the cultured cells were quantified by real-time PCR.Results: It was shown that expression of TBC1D20 mRNA in HepG2 and huh7 cell lines had been suppressed in dose-dependent fashion by interferon 2a (IFN-2a) (p \ 0.05). Quantitative RT-PCR showed that the abundance of TBC1D20 mRNA decreased by roughly 90% following treatment with IFN-2a (1,000 U/ml) .Here we show there was no potential role of ribavirin in expression of TBC1D20 mRNA in HepG2 and Huh7 cells (p [ 0.05). No synergistic effect on suppression of human TBC1D20 mRNA by interferon 2a (IFN2a) and ribavirin were found (p [ 0.05). Conclusions: These results raise the possibility that suppressing the expression of TBC1D20 in host hepatocytes may be one of the antiviral mechanisms of Interferon-2a.Ain Shams University, Faculty of Pharmacy, Abbasia, Cairo, Egypt, 2 Tanta University, Faculty of Medicine, Tanta,Faculty of Medicine

TABREF134.text: Efficacy of New PEG-Interferon a-2a (Reiferon Retard Ò ) plus Ribavirin in Egyption Patients with Chronic Hepatitis C Genotype 4 Gamal Shiha 1 , Shahera El-Etreby 2 , Khaled Zalata 3 , Waleed Samir 4 Medical 1,2 and Pathology 3 Departments, Biochemical Laboratory of Mansoura Specialized Hospital,4  Mansoura University, EgyptBackground: The standard of care for chronic hepatitis C (CHC) is a combination of ribavirin plus pegylated interferon (PEG-interferon alfa-2b, 12KDa or PEG-interferon alfa-2a, 40KDa). The sustained virological response (SVR) in treatment of CHC genotype 4 using this combination therapy for 48 weeks is about 60%. Objective: Assessment of the efficacy of a novel 20-KDa linear PEG interferon a-2a (Reiferon Retard Ò ) derived from Hansenula polymorha expression system combined with Ribavirin for treatment of CHC genotype 4. Patients and methods: One hundred and four patients biopsy proven CHC genotype 4 assigned to receive a fixed weekly dose of 160 lg of the PEG interferon (Reiferon Retard Ò ) in combination with Ribavirin 13 mg/kg and were followed up by PCR after 3, 6, 12 and 18 months. End of treatment response (ETR) defined as lose of detectable HCV RNA by PCR at week 48, SVR rate defined as lose of detectable HCV RNA by PCR at week 72 (24 weeks post-treatment) and possible side effects o the drug were reported. Results: One hundred and four patients (19 females and 85 males) received the treatment for 48 weeks, At 12 weeks the overall early response was 54%, ERT at 48 weeks was 43.2% and SVR at 72 weeks revealed an overall response rate Treatment of CHC genotype 4 with once weekly Reiferon Retard Ò plus Ribavirin for 48 weeks produces only 25% SVR which is significantly lower than other PEG-interferons.Outcomes of Conseus Interferon and Riba Therapy for Chronic Hep C G3Patients Who Relapsed with Previous Peg-Interferon and Riba Therapy Uzma Adeeb 1 , Fatima Khatak 1 , Muzzaffar Gill 1Maroof International Hospital F 10 Markaz IslamabadAims and objectives: There are no published studies about the efficacy of consensus interferon and Riba combination in chronic hepatitis C (G3) relapsers wiith Peginterferon Riba combination therapy. To evaluate the efficacy of consensus interferon and Ribavirin in patients previously treated with pegylated interferon and ribavirin combination therapy. We consecutively enrolled 20 patients with chronic hepatitis C G3 who relapsed with previous treatment with pegylated interferon for atleast 6 months. Methods: The study was conducted between February 2009 to September 2009. Inclusion criteria: Chronic hepatitis C G3 relapsers patients with documented history of Pegylated interferon and Ribavirin therapy for 6 months. Exclusion criteria: Active psychiatric history, platelet count \75,000, INR [1.5, S. Albumin \2.5, portal vein diameter [13 mm on ultrasound and active ischemic heart disease. All enrolled patients have CBC, ALT, HCV PCR quantitative, HCV genotype, thyroid function tests and blood sugar. Patients were given 15 lg thrice weekly consensus interferon and Ribavirin 400 mg bid.The treatment duration was for 6 months. Patients were reviewed 4 weekly basis for clinical examination and CBC. We did check HCV PCR quantitative at week 12. The patients who had HCV PCR negative or 50% reduction in HCV PCR at week 12 were given further 3 months of therapy. Results: Among 20 patients 15 were male and 5 were female. Median age was 45. Median viral load was 900,000 IU/ml .Sixteen out of 20 (80%) patients were HCVPCR negative at week 12 of therapy. These 16 patients completed further 12 weeks of therapy and remained HCVPCR negative at end of total 24 weeks of therapy. Two patients required filgrastin to keep neutrophil count in normal range. Conclusion: Consensus interferon (infergen) Ribavirin combination is very optimistic option for HEP C G3 relapsers with Peg Interferon Riba combination. Further studies are needed to confirm/refute these observation. We did give 6 months of therapy because of financial consideration.Occurrence of Hepatocellular Carcinoma after Achieving Sustained Virological Response to Interferon Therapy for Chronic Hepatitis C Rika Ishii 1 , Takafumi Saito 1 , Hisayoshi Watanabe 1 , Kazuo Okumoto 1 , Yuko Nishise 1 , Jun-Itsu Ito 1 , Koji Saito 1 , Hitoshi Togashi 2 , Sumio Kawata 1 Department of Gastroenterology Yamagata University Faculty of Medicine, 2-2-2 Iida-Nishi Yamagata Yamagata Japan, 2 Yamagata University Health Administration Center, 1-4-12 Kojirakawamachi Yamagata Yamagata Japan Background: Interferon (IFN) therpy has been reported to improve serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) levels, hepatic inflammation and fibrosis. Complete eradication of HCV reduces the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in patients with chronic hepatitis C (CHC). Although, several cases have been reported that HCC developed in patients after achieving sustained virological response (SVR) to interferon therapy. Methods: We identified four patients who developed HCC despite SVR (male 3, female 1). Result: The mean age of the patients was 65.0 years and the mean interval until detection of the initial HCC after achievement of SVR was 46.8 months. Activity of hepatitis and stage of fibrosis of noncancerous tissue were also determined according to the international standard classification before and after IFN therapy. At the time of HCC diagnosis, 3 remained noncirrhotic, but one had progressed to cirrhosis. The mean tumor size was 32.4 mm in diameter, and mean level of AFP and PIVKA-2 were 31.18 ng/ml (\10 ng/ml) and 64.3 mAU/ml (\40 mAU/ml), respectively. Pathological diagnosis was performed in each HCC, 4 of them were moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, and one was poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma. 3 patients underwent surgical treatment for initial HCC. However, one patient already had a metastasis of lymph node at the operation, and 6 months later, computed tomography revealed portal venous invasion. Another patient had multiple bone metastasis 3 years after the operation. One patient were treated with radiofrequency ablation, however, HCC recurrence progressed quickly in both patients. Conclusion: Thus, our findings suggest that CHC patients need for careful follow-up, even if they achieve SVR to IFN therapy.Peginterferon Alfa-2a (40KD) (PEGASYS Ò ) Plus Ribavirin (COPEGUS Ò ) has a Wide Safety Margin in Patients Infected with HCV Genotype 1 Patrick Marcellin 1 , Donald M. Jensen 2 , Stuart K. Roberts 3 , Stephanos J. Hadziyannis 4 , Gregory J. Dore 5 , Moisés Diago 6 , Martin Weltman 7 , Geoffrey W. McCaughan 8 , Wendy Cheng 9 , Darrell H. Crawford 10 , William Sievert 11 , William Rawlinson 12 , Jonathan Solsky 13 , Tobias Manigold 14 , Andreas Tietz 14 , Mario Rizzetto 15 Hôpital Beaujon, Clichy, France, 2 Center for Liver Diseases, Chicago, IL, USA, 3 The Alfred Hospital, Prahran, VIC, Australia, 4 Henry Dunant Hospital, Athens, Greece, 5 National Centre in HIV Epidemiology and Clinical Research, Sydney, NSW, Australia, 6 Hospital General De Valencia, Valencia, Spain, 7 Nepean Hospital, Sydney, NSW, Australia, 8 Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Sydney, NSW, Australia, 9 Royal Perth Hospital, Perth, WA, Australia, 10 Greenslopes Hospital, Brisbane, QLD, Australia, 11 Monash Medical Centre, Melbourne, VIC, Australia, 12 SEALS Microbiology, Sydney, NSW, Australia, 13 Roche Nutley, NJ, USA, 14 Roche Basel, Switzerland, 15 University of Torino, UOADU Gatro-Epatologia, Torino, Italy Background: Peginterferon alfa-2a (40KD) (PEGASYS Ò ) 180 lg/week has a well-established safety profile. Recent trials have explored the use of a high induction dose (360 lg/week for 12 weeks) in difficult-to-treat patients. The aim of this analysis was to examine the safety margin of standard versus high dose peginterferon alfa-2a (40KD).Methods: Data were pooled from four randomized multicenter trials including naive and treatment-experienced patients infected with hepatitis C virus genotype 1. Patients received peginterferon alfa-2a (40 KD) 180 or 360 lg/ week plus RBV 1,000/1,200 mg/day for 12 weeks (n = 1,549 and 863, respectively); after week 12, all patients received peginterferon alfa-2a (40 KD) 180 lg/wk. Safety outcomes were restricted to the first 12 weeks of treatment and included all adverse events (AEs), serious AEs (SAEs), laboratory abnormalities, treatment discontinuations, and dose modifications. Results: Demographics were similar for both groups with two-thirds of patients being male. Mean age was 45 versus 46 years (180 vs. 360 lg/week, respectively) and mean body mass index was 27 kg/m 2 in each group; a similar proportion of patients had bridging fibrosis or cirrhosis(19 vs. 23%). The overall reporting frequency of AEs and SAEs was similar in both groups and the same percentage of patients discontinued treatment for safety reasons (seetable). Significant predictors for discontinuation were Black race (p = 0.034) and lower serum albumin (p = 0.034), but not starting dose of peginterferon alfa-2a (40 KD) or gender. Conclusion: Administration of a high dose of peginterferon alfa-2a (40 KD) for 12 weeks is well tolerated, indicating a wide safety margin for its use.

Each patient was given conventional interferon alpha 2b thrice a week + Ribavirin 800 mg daily for 6 months. After 6 months of treatment, qualitative PCR for HCV RNA was carried out to know End of Treatment Response. Those found PCR negative were declared as ETR responders. Results: The age of the patients ranged from 15 to 63 years with a mean age (±SD) of 35.8 ± 8.7 years. Eighty-seven percent were married. Out of them, 433 cases (72.8%) were categorized as Responders based on clearance of virus as determinant by PCR. The End of Treatment Response (ETR) was 72.8%. The success rate is similar to other studies from Pakistan and abroad.Rapid Virological Response is a Predictor of Sustained Virological Response in Chronic Hep C G3 Patients Treated with Pegasys and RibavirinUzma Adeeb 1 , Fatima Khattak 1 , Gill Muzzaffar 1Maroof International Hospital, Markez F10 IslamabdIntroduction: Genotype (GT) is generally considered the most important predictor of sustained virological response (SVR). Role of viral clearance at week 4 i.e. rapid virological response (RVR) to predict SVR is not adequately studied in Chronic HepC G3 patients. We wanted to study the importance of rapid virological response (RVR) to predict SVR in chronic HepC G3 patients. Aims & Methods: A prospective study was conducted in our institution between January 2008 to January 2009. 150 consecutive chronic Hep C G3 patients eligible for treatment were enrolled in this study. They were given 180 ucg of pegasys weekly along with Ribavirin 400 mg twice daily. Treatment duration was for 6 months. They were seen in outpatient clinic on 4 weekly basis.Quantitativ HCVPCR was done at baseline at week 4, week 12 and week 24 during treatment and then 6 months after the completion of treatment to establish SVR.RVR was defined as HCVRNA \50 IU/ml at week of therapy Complete EVR was defined as HCVPCR \50 IU/ml at week 12 of therapy and partial EVR was defined as [2log10 drop in HCVPCR at week 12 of therapy. Results: Out of 150 patients 140 were available for analysis. Median age was 44, median ALT was 90, median HCVPCR was 850,000 IU/ml. Logistic regression analysis was done. RVR was considered independent/predictor variable and SVR (sustained virological response) was considered dependent/outcome variable.100 out of 150 (67%) patients had RVR and SVR in that group was 88%. 30 patients had EVR (20%) and SVR was 60%. Conclusion: Rapid virological response (RVR) is a good predictor of Sustained virological response (SVR) in HCV G3 patients. Patients who do not have RVR but EVR may need therapy for 9 months to a year. Further studies are needed to confirm this observation.PP339Outcomes of Chronic HepC G3 Cirrhotics Treated with Pegintron and Ribavirin Uzma Adeeb 1 , Fatima Khatak 1 , Muzzaffar Gill 1Maroof International Hospital, Markez F10 IslamabdIntroduction: Treating HCV cirrhotics is very controversial and difficult. Aims & Methods: This study was conducted in our institution from January 2007 to January 2008. 50 consecutive Hep C G3 compensated cirrhotics (child B) were included in this study. Results: Out of 50 patients 5 patients lost to F/U.22 out of 50 (44%) patients were HCVPCR negative at week 4 and 24.This was labelled as group A. After 6 months completion of therapy 20 patients (40%) were HCVPCR negative (SVR). Twelve out of 50 (25%) patients were negative at week 12 and week 24.This group was labelled as group B. Six months after completion of therapy 8 patients (16%) were HCVPCR negative (SVR). Nine patients were HCVPCR positive after 12 weeks of therapy and were labelled as non responders. Conclusion: Overall treatment response is significantly lower in HEP C G3 Cirrhotics. 4 week stopping role in this patient population may be considered to avoid unnecessary complications of treatment. TABREF138.text: Efficacy of the Currently Recommended Ribavirin Dose in Koreans: Need for Reassessment of Ribavirin Dosing Regimen Dong Hyun Sinn 1 , Jeong Kim 2 , Seung Woon Paik 2 , Su Rin Shin 3 , Geum-Youn Gwak 2 , Moon Suk Choi 2 , Joon Hyeok Lee 2 , Kwang Cheol Koh 2 , Byung Chul Yoo 2 Department of Medicine, Armed Forces Capital Hospital, Seongnam, 2 Department of Medicine Samsung Medical Center, Sungkyunkwan University School of Medicine, Seoul, 3 Department of Medicine, Kangnam Sacred Hospital, Hallym University, SeoulBackground: Recently, guidelines suggest 1,000 or 1,200 mg of ribavirin according to body weight for the treatment of patients infected with genotype 1 hepatitis C virus (HCV), which aims to give 13-15 mg/kg of ribavirin for most of patients. However, due to the smaller stature of Koreans, the current recommended ribavirin dose results in a higher ribavirin dose, especially for lowweight patients, but the efficacy of the current ribavirin dosing has not been thoroughly assessed. Methods: A total of 129 treatment naïve genotype 1 chronic hepatitis C patients were reviewed retrospectively.Result: The ribavirin dose was C16 mg/kg in 57 patients (44%) and \16 mg/ kg in 72 patients (56%). The patients with a higher ribavirin dose (C16 mg/kg) experienced more ribavirin associated side effects (60 vs. 24%, p \ 0.001) as well as a significant lower ribavirin adherence (mean of 0.71 vs. 0.81, p = 0.025), but the sustained virologic response (SVR) was similar (63 vs. 65%, p = 0.803). A ribavirin dose of C16 mg/kg was not an independent factor associated with SVR, while it was an independent risk factor for ribavirin associated side effects. Conclusion: Our findings suggest that the current ribavirin dosing regimen should be reassessed for Korean patients with RBV dose C16 mg/kg. Methods: In PROPHESYS 1, data are collected from patients receiving peginterferon alfa-2a (PEGASYS Ò ) plus ribavirin (RBV, COPEGUS Ò ). Results: Overall, 2,781 patients received peginterferon alfa-2a/RBV (PROPHESYS 1/2/3; table). In PROPHESYS 2/3, 495 G1/4 patients received peginterferon alfa-2a/RBV (n = 422) or peginterferon alfa-2b/RBV (n = 73). By MLR factors significantly associated with viral clearance in G1 patients were Asian In this large cohort, patient demographics differed by genotype. Roberts 10 Greenslopes Hospital, Brisbane, QLD, Australia, 2 National Centre in HIV Epidemiology and Clinical Research, Sydney, NSW, Australia, 3 Roche Products, Sydney, NSW, Australia, 4 Nepean Hospital, Sydney, NSW, Australia, 5 Royal Perth Hospital, Perth, WA, Australia, 6 Monash Medical Centre and Monash University, Melbourne, VIC, Australia, 7 Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Sydney, NSW, Australia, 8 SEALS, Prince of Wales Hospital, Sydney, NSW, Australia, 9 St Vincent's Hospital, Melbourne, VIC, Australia, 10 Alfred Hospital, Melbourne, VIC, AustraliaBackground: Rapid and early virological responses (RVR, EVR) predict the likelihood of sustained virological response (SVR) in hepatitis C virus (HCV) treatment. However, many studies investigating virological responses utilized assays with relatively high detection limits, reported qualitative data only, or did not adjust for baseline variables that influence SVR, such as hepatic fibrosis. Aim: To determine the probability of SVR in different fibrosis stages in relation to quantitative measurements of viral load at week 4 (VL 4 ), week 8 (VL 8 ) and week 12 (VL 12 ). Methods: 309 HCV genotype 1 subjects with prior liver biopsy were treated with peginterferon alfa-2a (40 KD) (PEGASUS Ò ) 180 lg/week and ribavirin (RBV; COPEGUS Ò ) 1,000/1,200 mg/day for 48 weeks in the CHARIOT study. VL 4, VL 8 and VL 12 were assessed using TaqMan TM (detection limit of 15 IU/mL). Multiple linear regression models were developed with significant baseline factors (race, Metavir score) and either VL 4 , VL 8 , or VL 12 . The probability of an SVR was estimated from these models for different levels of VL 4 , VL 8 , and VL 12 for Caucasians in different fibrosis stages. Results: Relationships among SVR, VL 4 , VL 8 , VL 12 , and fibrosis stage are illustrated (seefigure). Patients with stage F3/4 had a lower probability of achieving an SVR for each value of VL 4 , VL 8 , and VL 12 . For all fibrosis groups, the probability of achieving an SVR was generally higher for VL 4 and lower for VL 8 and VL 12 . Conclusions: Combining Metavir score with early viral load measurements can predict SVR in patients undergoing HCV treatment. Early on-treatment viral load measurement combined with severity of liver fibrosis may influence treatment decisions during therapy. This program ran from 2000 to 2007 in 55 countries. Potential predictors of dose reductions/discontinuations were analyzed by MLR. Results: Mean age was 44.7 years, 68.7% of patients were male, and 23.5% had cirrhosis. Asian patients were less likely to have cirrhosis (11.9%) than non-Asian patients (23.9%), but were of a similar age (43.6 vs. 44.7 years, respectively). Overall, 63.4 and 55.9% of patients completed 48 weeks' treatment with peginterferon alfa-2a (40 KD) and RBV, respectively, with Asian patients more likely to complete treatment; 6.6% experienced C1 SAE (3.2% treatment-related) and 44.0% experienced C1 non-serious AE of special interest. Twenty-eight patients (0.4%) died (two treatment-related). Dose modifications of peginterferon alfa-2a (40 KD) or RBV for AEs occurred in 24.4 and 16.2% of Asian patients and non-Asian patients, respectively; premature withdrawal for AEs occurred in 10.3 and 11.4% of patients. Increasing age predicted discontinuations of both drugs and female gender predicted discontinuation of RBV.PP357Efficacy of new PEG-Interferon a-2a (Reiferon Retard Ò ) Plus Ribavirin in Egyption Patients with Chronic Hepatitis C Gamal Shiha 1 , Shahera El-Etreby 1 , Khaled Zalata 1 , Waleed Samir 1 , Amira Elbeeh 2Mansoura University, Egypt, 2 Biotechnology Research Center, New Damitta, EgyptBackground: The standard of care for chronic hepatitis C (CHC) is a combination of ribavirin plus pegylated interferon (PEG-interferon alfa-2b, 12 KDa or PEG-interferon alfa-2a, 40 KDa). The sustained virological response (SVR) in treatment of CHC genotype 4 using this combination therapy for 48 weeks is about 60%. Objective: Assessment of the efficacy of a novel 20-KDa linear PEG interferon a-2a (Reiferon Retard Ò ) derived from Hansenula polymorha expression system combined with Ribavirin for treatment of CHC genotype 4. Patients and Methods: One hundred and four patients biopsy proven CHC genotype 4 assigned to receive a fixed weekly dose of 160 lg of the PEG interferon (Reiferon Retard Ò ) in combination with Ribavirin 13 mg/kg and were followed up by PCR after 3, 6, 12 and 18 months . End of treatment response (ETR) defined as lose of detectable HCV RNA by PCR at week 48, SVR rate defined as lose of detectable HCV RNA by PCR at week 72 (24 weeks post-treatment) and possible side effects of the drug were reported. Results: One hundred and four patients(19 females, 85 males) received the treatment for 48 weeks. At 12 weeks the overall early response was 54%, ERT at 48 weeks was 43.2% and SVR at 72 weeks revealed an overall response rate 25% viral clearance. Relapse rate was 42.2% (19/45) of patients. There were notably minimal haematologic complication. Conclusion: Treatment of CHC genotype 4 with once weekly Reiferon Retard Ò plus Ribavirin for 48 weeks produces only 25% SVR which is significantly lower than other PEG-interferons. Multidisciplinary interventions are needed in the short term while superior alternative antiviral therapy is desired in the long term to overcome barriers to treatmentPP359 A Need for a Dynamic Approach to Modelling Disease Progression in Cost-Effectiveness Studies of Antiviral Therapies in Patients with Chronic Hepatitis C Phil McEwan 1 , Yong Yuan 2 , Ray Kim 3 Cardiff Research Consortium, Eastgate House, 35-43 Newport Road, Cardiff, UK, CF24 0AB, 2 Bristol-Myers Squibb, Princeton, New Jersey, USA., 3 Mayo Clinc, Rochester, Minnesota, USABackground: Current models describing the natural history of chronic hepatitis C (CHC) use static rates of disease progression. This can have important implications for cost-effectiveness results obtained when modelling certain sub-groups, in particular, patients of advanced age. The aim of this study was to evaluate the impact of utilising age-dependent disease progression rates on the cost-effectiveness outcome obtained in a CHC model. Methods: A Markov model describing the natural history of CHC in genotype 1 patients was developed to estimate the cost-effectiveness of treatment with pegylated interferon and ribavarin versus interferon and ribavarin. The model was populated with data and validated using a previously published costeffectiveness model(Sullivan et al. 2004). The model was then re-calibrated using different rates of disease progression between CHC and compensated cirrhosis. A third party payer's perspective was adopted and the analysis was run over the patient's expected lifetime with costs and utility discounted at 3.5%. Results: The table below reports the cost per quality adjusted life year (QALY) obtained with age-independent (basecase) and age-dependent disease progression rates. The use of age-dependent progression rates has a considerable impact, particularly in patients of advanced age(65, 75)where the costeffectiveness results are improved by 40 and 30% respectively. Conclusion: Epidemiological studies that better characterise the rate of agedependent disease progression in CHC patients are needed if the evaluation of the cost-effectiveness of new interventions is to be robust and fit for purpose; particularly when considering treating patients of advanced age.PP360 Treatment of Chinese Patients with Chronic Hepatitis C with Peginterferon Alfa-2a (40 KD) plus Ribavirin (RBV) Ling-Li He 1 , Yang Chen 1 , Zhu Chen 1 , Hong Tang 1 , Bing-Jun Lei 1 , Xue-Zhong Lei 1 West China Hospital, Center for Infectious Diseases, Sichuan University, Sichuan, ChinaBackground: The combination of peginterferon plus ribavirin cures chronic hepatitis C in 50-60% of Western patients and is the standard of care for this condition; however, few data are available on the efficacy/safety of this combination in Chinese patients. Methods: We analyzed data from 108 patients treated for 48 weeks with peginterferon alfa-2a 180 lg/wk plus ribavirin 800 mg/day (if \65 kg) or 1,000 mg/day (if C65 kg) under care at Hua Xi Hospital between April 2004 and March 2008. HCV RNA was assessed at baseline, week 4 and 12, the end of treatment (EOT), and after 24 weeks' follow-up (sustained virological response; SVR) with a test range of 1.0 9 10 3 to 5.0 9 10 7 IU/mL. Patients were stratified by age, gender, route of transmission, duration of infection, baseline HCV RNA level and RBV dosage.Results: Of the 108 patients treated, 58 were female, mean age was 39 years and mean HCV RNA was 6.21 ± 0.82 IU/mL (range 3.98-7.70). HCV genotype was assessed in 29 patients (genotype 1b, 21; genotype 2a, 7; genotype 1b/2a, 1). Rapid virological response (RVR; HCV RNA negative at week 4), early virological response (EVR; HCV RNA negative at week 12), EOT response, and SVR were achieved in 84 (78%), 105 (98%), 105 (98%), and 95 (88%) patients, respectively (10 relapsed; 2 had breakthrough, 1 was a non-responder). Younger age, female gender, infection by a route other than surgery/blood product exposure, and RBV exposure [60% were associated with higher SVR rates. Patients with an RVR had higher SVR rates and lower relapse rates than patients with an EVR. Conclusion: Chinese patients treated with peginterferon alfa-2a plus ribavirin have high rates of RVR, EVR, and SVR. This analysis suggests that overall SVR rates in Chinese patients are higher than those typical of Western patients.Evaluation of Egyptian Patients with Chronic Hepatitis C Genotype 4 with Persistently Normal ALT Including Response to Antiviral Therapy Alyaa Sabry 1 , Naglaa Allam 1 , Medhat Asem 1 , Maha Allam 2 , Hana Badran 1 , Eman Rewisha 1 , Imam Waked 1 Hepatology, National Liver Institute, Shebeen Al-koam, Menofeya, Egypt, 2 Clinical Pathology, National Liver Institute, Shebeen Al-koam, Menofeya, Egypt Background and Aims: Approximately 25% of patients with chronic hepatitis C (10-46%) present with persistently normal serum ALT (PNALT). In these individuals, the extent and rate of disease progression as well as the need for treatment remain controversial. Hence the aims of the present study were to compare between the fibrosis score in Egyptian chronic hepatitis C patients genotype 4 with PNALT and those with elevated ALT levels (EALT) and, in addition, to evaluate their response to treatment with pegylated interferon a-2a (180 lg weekly) and ribavirin. Methods: 206 patients attending the National Liver Institute from January 2005 to May 2009 were recruited. Normal ALT was set as \30 IU/ml in males; \19 IU/ ml in females on 3 consecutive measurements 2 months apart. 104 patients presented with EALT and 102 with PNALT. Fibrosis score, early (EVR), end of treatment (ETR) and sustained virological response (SVR) were assessed. Results: Patients with PNALT were younger and weighed less but the difference was not significant. Most of the patients with PNALT (73.5%) had mild fibrosis [F0-F2] versus 56% of patients with EALT (p = \ 0.01). Advanced fibrosis and high body mass index served as significant predictors of nonresponse to therapy in both groups. No significant difference between the two groups regarding ETR and SVR was detected. A significant correlation between the development of anemia on treatment and SVR in both EALT (p = \0.01) and PNALT (p = \0.05) was found. Conclusion: Treatment of patients with PNALT should not be deferred based only on their ALT profile and it should be individualised.

Rd., Taipei 100,  Taiwan,  No.100, Tzyou 1st Road Kaohsiung 807, Taiwan, Linkou, No.199, Tunghwa Rd., Taipei, Taiwan, 4 Taipei Veterans  General Hospital, No. 201, Sec. 2, Taipei 112, Taiwan, Kaoshiung, No. 123, Kaoshiung City, Taiwan, 6  Kaohsiung Veterans General Hospital, 386 Ta-Chung 1stRD. Taipei, Taiwan, No. 325, Sec.2,Chenggong Rd., Neihu District,Taipei City  114,Taiwan, 9 National Cheng Kung University Hospital, No.138,Sheng Li  Road,Tainan, Taiwan,  No. 482, Shanming Rd., Siaogang Dist., Kaohsiung City, Taiwan    Background/Aims: Peginterferon alfa plus ribavirin for 48 weeks (wks) is the standard treatment for genotype 1 chronic hepatitis C (CHC) in many countries. However, Taiwanese patients could obtain satisfactory treatment results with 24-week therapy. Whether 48-week therapy is superior to 24-week therapy in Taiwanese patients with genotype 1 CHC is unclear and needs investigation. Methods: In this open-label, randomized, multi-center study, treatment-naïve patients with genotype 1 CHC received peginterferon alfa-2b (1.5 lg/kg/wk) plus ribavirin(1,(0)(1)200 mg/day) for 24 weeks and were then randomized to discontinue or continue the treatment for 24 weeks further. The primary endpoint was sustained virologic response(SVR, undetectable HCV-RNA at  follow-up [FU]  week 24). Secondary endpoints included end-of-treatment (EOT) response and virologic response 48 weeks after randomization. Results: Totally 160 patients were enrolled (24-week treatment n = 78; 48-week treatment, n = 82). There were more male patients in the 24-week arm (74.4 vs. 52.4%, P = 0.004), and those who completed the treatment and FU was 69.2% in 24-week arm and 87.8% in 48-week arm. EOT response was similar between 24-and 48-week arms (85.9 vs. 84.2%). SVR tended to be lower in 24-week arm (56.4 vs. 67.1%; P = 0.165) indicating a higher relapse rate in those with 24-week treatment. At 48 weeks after randomization, virologic response rates were 67.1% in 48-week arm (FU week 24) and 57.7% in 24-week arm (FU week 48). Adverse events were more frequent in 48-week arm (76.83 vs. 58.97%, P = 0.015). Conclusions: No significant difference in SVR was detected between 24-week or 48-wk treatment for Taiwanese patients with genotype 1 CHC. However, the high drop-out rate in the 24-week arm should be taken into consideration when interpreting the results. There seemed a tendency of better response in the 48-week treatment.Nurse-Provided Therapeutic Education in Patients with Chronic Hepatitis C Treated By Peg-Interferon-Alpha2a-Ribavirin: Impact on Quality of Life Dominique Larrey 1,2 , Annie Salsé 1 , Christelle Castelli 3 , Marie-Cécile Bozonnat 3 , Gerges-Philippe Pageaux 1 , Didier Ribard 4 , Natalia Kharlov 5 , Jean-Pierre Daurès 3 , Study Group PEGOBS 1 Liver Unit, Saint-Eloi Hospital -Montpellier, 2 Unit 632, INSERM -Montpellier, 3 Biostatistics Department, IURC -Montpellier,4  Hepato-Gastroenterology, Caremeau Hospital -Nıˆmes,5 Clinical Research, Roche LaboratoryBackground: Recently, we reported that nurse-provided therapeutic education (TE), significantly increased adherence to treatment and virologic response in pts with chronic hepatitis C treated by Peg-Interferon-alpha2a-Ribavirin in a prospective multicentric randomized study (PEGOBS) (Larrey et al.Hepatology 2007; 46: 377 (310)). Aim: To evaluate the impact of TE on quality of life (QoL) during this study. Methods: PEGOBS included 123 pts in TE group versus 121 pts in control group with pragmatic follow-up (C). QoL was analyzed by 2 auto-questionnaires: SF36 (short form 36), with 8 dimensions, comprising 36 questions; NHP (Nottingham's Health Profil), with 38 questions. Comparative analysis of QoL was performed according to the course and duration of treatment and characteristics of pts. Results: NHP showed QoL alteration during the treatment, which was more important for the longer treatment, 48 versus 24 weeks (NHP score +39 points, p = 0.04, without difference between groups TE and C). SF36 allowed analysis by dimension and on physical and psychological scores. Overall, there was no difference between the 2 groups in all pts. These results suggest to improve TE method to find the best compromise balance between adherence, virological response and impact on QoL.PP364A Response-Guided-Therapy is Feasible in Peginterferon Plus Ribavirin Combination Therapy for Chronic Hepatitis C Patients with Genotype 1 and Amino Acid Substitutions in the Core Region Yoshiaki Iwasaki 1 , Fusao Ikeda 1 , Akinobu Takaki 1 , Testuya Yasunaka 1 , Yasuhiro Miyake 1 , Haruhiko Kobashi 1 , Kazuhide Yamamoto 1 Okayama University Graduate School of Medicine, Dentistry, and Pharmaceutical Sciences, 2-5-1, Shikata-cho, Kita-ku, Okayama 700-8558, JapanBackground/Aims: Recently, substitutions of amino acids 70 and 91 in the core region were shown to predict resistance to combination therapy of peginterferon plus ribavirin in patients with genotype 1 chronic hepatitis C. In this prospective cohort study, we sought a possibility of the response-guidedtherapy for these difficult-to-treat patients. Methods: A total of 75 patients chronically infected with hepatitis C virus (HCV) genotype 1 and high viral load (C100 KIU/mL) were treated with peginterferon alpha-2b (1.5 mg/kg weight) plus weight-based dosing of ribavirin. Results: Of 75 patients, 65 (87%) had no or one amino acid substitution in the ISDR. In the remaining three patients with LVR, two successfully achieved SVR and one relapsed after extended 72-week treatment. Conclusions: A response-guided-therapy is feasible even in patients with amino acid substitutions in the core region.Transfer of Hepatitis C Virus (HCV)-Reactive T Cell Specificity for the Treatment of HCV-Associated Hepatocellular Carcinoma Yue-Ying Liu 1 , Ya-Hui Zhang 1 , Lucy Golden-Mason 2 , Hugo Rosen 2 , Michael Nishimura 1 , Yi Zhang 1 Medical University of South Carolina, 86 Jonathan Lucas Street, Suite 512C, Charleston, SC 29425, USA, 2 University of Colorado, 12605 East 16th Avenue, Aurora, CO, 80045, USABackground: An approach have recently been described that retroviral vectors encoding T cell receptor (TCR) genes are used to redirect the specificity of normal peripheral blood lymphocyte (PBL)-derived T cells to recognize the tumor antigens. Methods: We have previously shown that HCV + liver transplant patients that have received HLA disparate liver allografts have HCV reactive T cells of host origin in their peripheral blood that are restricted by the donor HLA molecules. Conclusion: CCN2 is overexpressed in HCC, especially in surrounding stroma and neoateries, suggesting that CCN2 may play an important role in development of HCC.Rapamycin, a mTOR Inhibitor, Prevents Hepatocellular CarcinomaDevelopment in the DEN Induce Rat Ting-Bo Liang 1 , Wei Chen 1 , Xu-Ning Shen 1 , Guo-Dong Xu 1 , Rui-Dan Zhuang 1 , Tao Ma 1 , Jun-Jian Li 1 , Xue-Li Bai 1 1 Departments of Hepatobiliary and Pancreatic Surgery, Key Laboratory of Multi-Organ Transplantation of Ministry of Public Health, the First Affiliated Hospital, School of Medicine, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310003, PR ChinaPurpose: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the fifth common malignant tumors worldwide. These findings indicated rapamycin would be a chemopreventive and chemotherapive agent for HCC.Background: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is one of the top three most common malignant tumors in China. Methods: Real-time quantitative PCR and immunohistochemistry were performed to examine the expression of EZH2 in human primary HCC samples. Decrease or deletion of PTEN protein expression may not be able to inhibit Ras/Raf/MEK/ERK signaling pathway,this will result in carcinogenesis,invasiveness and metastasis.Top 10% PostersThe Diagnostic Sensitivity of AASLD Guideline on Hepatocellular Carcinoma and its Application on Non-cirrhotic Patients Ming-Tzung Lin 1,2 , Tsung-Hui Hu 1,2 , Yu-Feng Cheng 1,3 , Hock-Liew Eng 1,4 , Chih-Chi Wang 1,5 , Chao-Long Chen 1,5 1 Chang Gang Memorial Hospital-Kaohsiung Medical Center, 123,Ta-Pei Road, Niaosung Hsiang, Kaohsiung Country, 833, Taiwan, R.O.C., 2 Division of Hepato-Gastroenterology, Department of Internal Medicine, 123, Ta-Pei Road, Niaosung Hsiang, Kaohsiung Country, 833, Taiwan, R.O.C., 3 Radiology, 123, Ta-Pei Road, Niaosung Hsiang, Kaohsiung Country, 833, Taiwan, R.O.C., 4 Pathology, 123, Ta-Pei Road, Niaosung Hsiang, Kaohsiung Country, 833, Taiwan, R.O.C, 5 Surgery, 123, Ta-Pei Road, Niaosung Hsiang, Kaohsiung Country, 833, Taiwan, R.O.C.Background: The American Association for the Study of Liver Disease(AASLD, 2005)  issued guidelines to propose a diagnostic approach for HCC. HCC diagnosis can be made by dynamic images or AFP in a cirrhosis liver. In non-cirrhotic liver, biopsy is suggested. Methods: From January 2006 to November 2008, total 343 pathologically diagnosed HCC patients via surgical resection were reviewed. 124 patients were excluded for final analysis (AASLD guideline sensitivity) due to inadequate information (including image or AFP). Finally, 219 patients were enrolled for final analysis. Pre-operative cirrhosis was diagnosed by ultrasonography using scoring system C8 Tumor sizes were recorded by pathologic report. Pathologic cirrhosis was verified by modified Knodell classification as fibrosis score: 4. Results: The accuracy of cirrhotic diagnosis by ultrasonography was 72.9% preoperatively. Diagnostic sensitivity of HCC by single image study was around 65-80%, with a very low value for HCC \2 cm. Among these 219 patients, the sensitivity of HCC diagnosis according to AASLD guideline was 89.7% in image-cirrhotic patients, and 92.2% in image non-cirrhotic patients.

TABREF298.text: LAPTM4B-35 Combined with ASS as a Novel Prognostic Biomarker for Hepatocellular Carcinoma Patients after Hepatectomy Hua Yang 1 , Fu-Xia Xiong 1 , Ming Lin 1 , Rui-Zhao Qi 2 , Zhen-Wen Liu 2 , Jing-An Rui 2 , Xiu Nie 3 , Rou-Li Zhou 1 1 Department of Cell Biology, School of Basic Medical Sciences, Peking University, Beijing, 100191, China, 2 Department of Liver and Gallbladder Surgery, the People's Liberation Army 302 Hospital, Beijing, 100039, China, 3 Department of Pathology, Union Hospital Affiliated to Tongji Medical College, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430022, ChinaBackground/Aims: A newly identified lysosomal protein transmembrane 4 beta-35 (LAPTM4B-35) plays important roles in tumor progression and metastasis, while argininosuccinate synthetase (ASS) provides arginine as an indispensable nutrient for HCC. This study aimed to elucidate the prognostic significance of LAPTM4B-35 and ASS proteins as biomarkers in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) patients. Methods: Expressions of LAPTM4B-35 and ASS in HCCs and paired noncancerous liver tissues were evaluated by Western blot (WB) and/or Immunohistochemistry (IHC). The correlations of LAPTM4B-35 and ASS expressions with clinicopathologic parameters were assessed by chi-squared test. Patient survival was determined by Kaplan-Meier method and log-rank test. Cox regression was adopted for multivariate analysis of prognostic factors. Results: LAPTM4B-35 staining was markedly enhanced in 74.3% of HCC specimen. ASS expression was negative in 70.4% of HCC samples. Overexpression of LAPTM4B-35 and positive expression of ASS were both significantly associated with pathologic grading, TNM stage, portal vein invasion and recurrence of HCC. On multivariate analysis, combined LAPTM4B-35 and ASS expression showed markedly poorer overall survival and disease-free survival than patients with HCC that were negative for both of these proteins or positive for one and negative for the other (P = 0.039 and P = 0.035, respectively). Conclusions: Overexpression of LAPTM4B-35 in combination with positive expression of ASS is an independent biomarker of poor prognosis for HCC patients after hepatectomy.Top 10% PostersUpregulation of Osteopontin Encourages Tumor Growth and Metastasis of Human Hepatocellular Carcinoma Qiong-Zhu Dong 1,2 , Chun Dai 1,2 , Hai-Jun Zhou 1,2 , Hu-Liang Jia 1,2 , Ning Ren 1,2 , Qing-Hai Ye 1,2 , Lun-Xiu Qin 1,2 1 Liver Cancer Institute, Fudan University, Shanghai, China, Room 610, Mingdao Building, Dong'an Road 130#, Shanghai, China, 2 Institutes of Biomedical Sciences, Fudan University, Shanghai, China, Room 610, Mingdao Building, Dong'an Road 130#, Shanghai, ChinaBackground: Hepatic metastasis is a primary cause for failure of locoregional therapy in Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC). In addition, we evaluated the influence of OPN on the cell proliferation and the signal pathway induced by OPN. Results: The expression levels of OPN were significantly increased in primary HCC tumors and their secondary metastatic lesions compared with surrounding non-cancerous tissue. In the transfected cells, up-regulation of OPN resulted in a remarkably increased ability of cell adhesion (56.08 ± 2.0) and the migrating cell numbers (25.2 ± 2.08) compared withMock (49.93 ± 1.74, 17.4 ± 1.45)   (P \ 0.05). Furthermore, up-regulation of OPN promoted the in vivo tumor growth and metastasis of human HCC cells. In addition, the cell proliferation was influenced by the concentration of exogenous recombinant OPN. OPN could induce the expression of MMP2 and uPA, and activate the AKT-Survivin pathway. Conclusions: Both in vitro and in vivo assays suggested that OPN could promote the invasion and metastasis of HCC. OPN contributed to HCC growth and metastasis possibly by activated AKT-Survivin pathway. The aim of this study is to investigate whether measurement of both PIVKA-II and AFP every 3 months can detect small HCC (B3 cm) better than conventional surveillance. Methods: In this prospective study which began since June 2007, cirrhotic patients (n = 674) with Child A were randomly allocated to group I (AFP+PIVKA-II q 3mo, n = 298) and group II (AFP q 6 mo, n = 376). All patients underwent surveillance ultrasonography every 6 months. The tumor characteristics and outcomes were compared between two groups. Results: In all patients, the mean age was 53.7 years (433 men and 241 women). The main etiology was hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection (n = 505, 74.9%). The baseline mean Child-Pugh score was 5.1 ± 0.5, and liver stiffness measurement (LSM) score was 18.6 ± 14.1 kPa. During the median follow-up of 16.7 months, 35 (5.2%) patients were diagnosed as HCC (12 in group I and 23 in group II). The LSM score was higher in HCC patients (20.5 ± 16.1 kPa) compared to non-HCC patients (18.5 ± 14.0 kPa) without statistical significance (P = 0.45). In group I, two cases (16.7%) were diagnosed as HCC only due to elevated PIVKA-II. In comparison of group I and II, the number of uninodular HCC was 8 (66.7%) and 18 (78.3%), respectively. There was no significant difference of mean tumor size (3.5 ± 3.3 cm vs. 3.1 ± 2.0 cm, P = 0.62), and number of single HCC B3 cm was 9 (75.0%) and 14 (60.9%), respectively (P = 0.48). The 2-year cumulative survival rate was 91% in group I and 89% in group II (P = 0.63). Conclusion: Combined measurement of AFP and PIVKA-II every 3 months with 6-month ultrasonography did not detect early HCC more than standard surveillance. Results: Among the 3 PET parameters tested, Tsuvmax/Lsuvmax (cutoff value of 1.45) was the most significant predictor of treatment response. Comparison of 7 Staging Systems in North Indian Cohort of Hepatocellular Carcinoma Balkrishan Sharma 1 , Sanjay Sarma 1 , Yogesh Kumar Chawla 1 , Shweta Kapil 1 , Bhupesh Singla 1 , Naveen Kalra 2 , Arunashu Behera 3 , Ajay Duseja 1 , Radha Krishan Dhiman 1 1 Departments of Hepatology 1 , Radiology 2 & General Surgery 3 , Post Graduate Institute of Medical Education and Research, Chandigarh, IndiaBackground & aim: Many liver staging systems have been proposed for patients with hepatocellular carcinoma; however it is still controversial which staging system is best. The aim of this study was to compare the ability of seven different staging systems (Okuda staging, TNM, CLIP, BCLC, JIS, Tokyo score and GRETCH staging) in predicting survival in an Indian cohort of patients with HCC. Patients and methods: In this prospective study 101 HCC patients were diagnosed and stratified according to 7 different staging systems; along with analysis of independent predictors of survival and their correlation with survival was evaluated Results: CLIP, Tokyo score and BCLC staging system showed a significant difference in the probability of survival according to the Kaplan-Meier method. All other staging systems failed to show a significant difference in survival. The P value for CLIP, Tokyo score and BCLC staging were 0.03, 0.05 and 0.05 respectively. TABREF302.text: Judgement of Biological Malingnant Potential by Combination Diagnosis of Gd-EOB-DTPA MRI and Sonazoid-contrast Enhanced Ultrasonography in Hepatocellular CarcinomaMitsuaki Sato 1,2 , Kaoru Tsuchiya 1 , Nobuharu Tamaki 1 , Tomohiro Tanaka 1 , Itsuko Hirayama 1 , Yutaka Yasui 1 , Ken Ueda 1 , Teiji Kuzuya 1 , Jun Itakura 1 , Hiroyuki Nakanishi 1 , Masayuki Kurosaki 1 , Yasuhiro Asahina 1 , Nobuyuki Enomoto 2 , Namiki Izumi 1 1 Musashino Red-Cross Hospital, Kyonancho1-26-1, Musashino-shi, Tokyo, Japan, 2 First Department of Internal Medicine, Faculty of Medicine, University of Yamanashi, 1110 Shimokato, Chuo-shi, Yamanashi, Japan Background: Clinically, it is important to treat HCC whose biological malignant potential is high. It suggested that 250 lg/L of AFP seems a more suitable diagnostic value for PHC than 400 lg/L.AFPL3% versus AFP in Diagnosis of HCC in Egyptian PatientsAli Nada 1 , Naglaa Allam 1 , Eman Rewisha 1 , Mohsen Salama 1 , Ahmed Abbas 1 1 National Liver Institute, Menofeya, EgyptBackground: The global incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is rising and in Egypt a threefold increase between 19 and 2008 has been reported. Diagnostic Value of Lectin-reactive alpha-fetoprotein (AFP-L3) and des-gamma-carboxy prothrombin (DCP) for Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC): First Study with a Turkish Patient Cohort A. Studies on Japanese and American patient cohorts suggest improved diagnosis of HCC by the additional determination of Lens culinaris agglutinin-reactive AFP (AFP-L3) and of desgamma-carboxy prothrombin (DCP).1,2  The aim of this study was to evaluate the clinical utility of AFP-L3 and DCP in a Turkish patient cohort. Methods: From 01/2008 to 03/2009 118 patients with mostly HBV and HCV infection were studied. 89 of them had proven HCC and 29 had liver cirrhosis. AFP, the fraction of Lectin-reactive AFP (AFP-L3%) and DCP were measured using the LiBASys TM automated immunological analyzer (Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd, Japan). The following cutoffs were used for the markers: AFP [ 13 ng/ml, AFP-L3 [ 10% and DCP [ 3,0 ng/ml. Results: Levels of AFP, AFP-L3% and DCP were higher in patients with HCC. The sensitivity, specificity, positive and negative predictive value for AFP was 53, 93, 96 and 39%, for AFP-L3% 37, 93, 94 and 33% and for DCP 58, 83, 91 and 40% respectively. The sensitivity could be increased to 72% by using all three markers, whereas the specificity decreased to 79%. In contrast to AFP and AFP-L3, DCP showed a strong correlation with tumor diameter and portal vein invasion. Conclusions: The exclusive determination of the routinely used marker AFP showed a fair sensitivity of 53%. The sensitivity of the investigated markers alone is slightly higher for DCP compared to AFP, but in combination the markers showed a significantly increased sensitivity. We should closely follow up the patients with AFP-L3 more than 7%.Bone as the First Site of Metastasis from Hepatocellular Carcinoma-Detection and Analysis by Dual-tracer PET/CT Chi-Lai Ho 1 , Sirong Chen 1 , Eric Yim Lung Leung 1 , Thomas Kam Chau Cheng 1 1 Hong Kong Sanatorium & Hospital, 2 Villiage Road, Happy Valley, Hong KongBackground: Dual-tracer PET/CT using 11 C-acetate (ACT) and 18 F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) has high sensitivity for the detection of primary and secondary hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). TABREF305.text: Osteopontin, a Single Marker for Predicting the Prognosis of Patients with the Tumor-Node-Metastasis (TNM) Stage I Hepatocellular Carcinoma after Surgical Resection Rong-Xin Chen 1 , Yun-Hong Xia 1 , Tong-Chun Xue 1 , Sheng-Long Ye1  1 Zhongshan Hospital & Liver Cancer Institute, Fudan University,  Shanghai, No.180 Fenglin Road, Shanghai, China    Osteopontin (OPN) has been linked to clinical outcomes in several solid tumors. However, it is not fully evaluated whether OPN could be used as a single marker for the prognosis of patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), particularly in those patients with the tumor-node-metastasis (TNM) stage I HCC. A total of 151 patients with HCC who underwent surgical resection were enrolled, including 112 patients of the TNM stage I. OPN expression was evaluated using immunohistochemistry in the tissue microarrays derived from these patients. Immunoreactivity was classified according to the percentage and intensity of staining: negative (-), weak (+) and strong (++). The impact of OPN expression on survival of patients was analyzed. In total, 65.6% (99 of 151) of HCC tissues expressed OPN. The overall survival (OS) rates in patients of OPN (-) group were significantly higher than those of OPN (+) or OPN (++) group (P = 0.049 and P = 0.001). OPN was an unfavorable prognostic factor for OS, but not for disease-free survival (DFS). Interestingly, in the TNM stage I HCC, OPN expression was correlated with the early recurrence after surgical resection (P = 0.001). Further analysis showed that OPN expression was an independent prognostic factor for OS and DFS in patients with the TNM stage I HCC (hazard ratio, 2.272, P = 0.014 and 1.982, P = 0.037). These results suggest that OPN expression is common in HCC and it is a useful marker for predicting the prognosis of patients with the TNM stage I HCC, contributing to determining which individual patients need adjuvant therapy to prevent the early recurrence after surgical resection.Detection of the Altered Expression of DDAH-1 in Hepatocellular Carcinoma by Using Laser Capture Microdissection and Proteome Analysis Qing Wang 1 , He-Ping Hu 1 1 Department of Gastroenterology, Eastern Hepatobiliary Surgery Hospital, The Second Military Medical University, 225 Changhai Road, Shanghai, 200438, PR China

TABREF306.text: Regulatory T Cells are Associated with Tumor Metastasis and Poor Survival in Hepatocellular Carcinoma Patients Jun-Liang Fu 1 , Shao-Jun Xing 1 , Lin Zhou 1 , Ming Shi 1 , Zheng Zhang 1 , Bao-Yun Fu 1 , Lei Jin 1 , Fu-Sheng Wang 1 1 Research Center for Biological Therapy, 302 Hospital of Peking University, 100 Xi Si Huan Middle Road, Beijing, China Background & Aims: Recent studies have demonstrated that CD4 + CD25 + regulatory T cells (Treg) are increased and linked to compromised immune responses in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma(HCC). This study attempts to further characterize the association between FoxP3 + Treg and tumor metastasis of HCC. Methods: One-hundred and thirty HCC patients with chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection (designated as HBV-related HCC patients), including 40 patients without tumor metastasis, 58 patients with local metastasis (LM) and 32 patients with distant metastasis (DM), 26 HBV-related liver cirrhosis (LC) patients, and 35 normal controls were enrolled. Flow cytometric, immunohistochemical, and immunosuppressive assays were employed for analyses of property of Treg. Multivariate analysis of prognostic factors for overall survival was made using Cox's proportional hazards model. Results: Both circulating and tumor resident FoxP3 + Treg were significantly increased and correlated with disease progression in HCC patients. HCC patients with tumor metastasis had higher FoxP3 + Treg than patients without tumor metastasis, and DM patients had significantly higher FoxP3 + Treg than LM patients. We also found that a large numbers of FoxP3 + Treg infiltrated in tumor embolus and metastatic HCC tissues in other organs. The increased suppressive function of Treg in tumor region was found in tumor regions compared with non-tumor regions. Furthermore, circulating Treg of HCC patients with tumor metastasis displayed an increased suppression on effector T cells compared with patients without tumor metastasis. Importantly, increased numbers of circulating Treg were associated with high mortality and reduced survival time of HCC patients with metastasis. Conclusion: Increased FoxP3 + Treg may promote tumor metastasis and disease progression in HCC patients. Manipulation of Treg function maybe a promising strategy for prevention of HCC metastasis and relapse.Association of the Single Nucleotide Polymorphism of IL-10 and ALDH2 with Hepatocellular Carcinoma Zhi Du 1 , Ying-Tang Gao 1 , Juan-Juan Liu 1 , Bin Yang 1 , Tao Han 2 , Yi-Jun Wang 3 , Feng-Mei Wang 2 , Jing Xiang 3 1 Key Laboratory of Artificial Cell, Institute for Hepatobiliary Disease, Tianjin Third Central Hospital, Tianjin, China, Jintang Road 83, Hedong District, Tianjin 300170, 2 Department of Hepatology, Tianjin Third Central Hospital, Tianjin, China, Jintang Road 83, Hedong District, Tianjin 300170, 3 Department of Hepatobiliary Surgery, Tianjin Third Central Hospital, Tianjin, China, Jintang Road 83, Hedong District, Tianjin 300170

TABREF308.text: Changing Etiology of Hepatocellular Carcinoma in North Indian HCC Patients Balkrishan Sharma 1 , Yogesh Chawla 1 , Shweta Kapil 1 , Bhupesh Singla 1 , Kiran Kumar 1 , Ajay Duseja 1 , Radha Krishan Dhiman 1 , Naveen Kalra 2 Departments of Hepatology 1 & Radiology 2 Post Graduate Institute of Medical Education and Research, Chandigarh, India Background: Hepatitis viruses (B & C) are the major risk factors for the development of HCC. However there is scanty information regarding the epidemiology of HCC from India. Aim: To study the epidemiological changes of HCC in north Indian HCC patients. Material and methods: 212 HCC patients were included in this study who attended the Liver Clinic of PGIMER, Chandigarh from January 2005 to December 2009 and divided in five groups year wise. Group 1: 35 HCC patients (2005); group2: 43 HCC patients (2006); group3: 39 (2007); group 4: 48 HCC patients (2008); group 5: 47 HCC patients (2009) HCC patients. All the biochemical, haematological and clinical history were recorded and various parameters were compared within and among groups. Results: HBsAg and antiHCV were positive in 55 and 33% in group 1, 54 and 32% in group 2, 55 and 28% in group 3 and 51 and 29% in group 4, respectively. However in group 5, 60% patients were found to have HCV infection, only 17% patients were with HBV infection and 23% were of unknown etiology. Metabolic Syndrome is an Independent Risk Factor of Hepatocellular Carcinoma Recurrence after Curative Treatment in Non-B Non-C Chronic Liver Disease Patients Takamasa Ohki 1 , Ryosuke Tateishi 2 , Shuichiro Shiina 2 , Miwako Kakiuchi 1 , Naminatsu Takahara 1 , Kenichiro Enooku 2 , Eriko Goto 2 , Ryota Masuzaki 2 , Yuji Kondo 2 , Michiharu Seki 1 , Tadashi Goto 2 , Nobuo Toda 1 , Haruhiko Yoshida 2 , Kazumi Tagawa 1 , Masao Omata 3 , Kazuhiko Koike 2 1 Mitsui Memorial Hospital Department of Gastorenterology, Chiyodaku Kandaizumicho Ichibanchi Tokyo, 2 University of Tokyo, Department of Gastroenterology, Bunkyoku Hongo 7-3-1 Tokyo, 3 Yamanashi Prefectural Central Hospital, Koufu City Fujimi 1-1-1 Yamanashi Prefecture, JapanBackground: Several articles reported that metabolic syndrome (MS) could increase the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) development in chronic liver disease patients. However, it is not fully elucidated whether MS increases the risk of HCC recurrence after curative treatment in non-B non-C chronic liver disease patients. We conducted this study to investigate whether MS is a risk factor of HCC recurrence after curative treatment in non-B non-C chronic liver disease patients. Methods: We enrolled 137 naïve, non-B non-C HCC patients including alcoholic and non-alcoholic chronic liver disease. All of them were curatively treated by percutaneous radiofrequency ablation (RFA) between 1999 and 2007. The diagnosis of MS was based on International Diabetes Federation criteria. Based on comorbidity with MS, patients were divided into two groups: the MS group (n = 44) and the normal group (n = 93). The effects of MS on HCC recurrence was analyzed together with other factors including tumor and liver function-related ones. Results: The cumulative recurrence rates significantly differed between the two groups (P = 0.019); 22.7, 62.6, and 72.6% at 1, 2, and 3 years, respectively, in the MS group and 15.8, 38.7, and 55.6% in the normal group. Multivariate analysis indicated higher age (HR 1.04, per 1 year, P = 0.026), comorbidity with diabetes mellitus (HR 1.67, P = 0.041), presence of MS (HR 2.05, P = 0.005), lower platelet counts (HR 0.93, per 10 3 /ll, P = 0.002), tumor multinodularity (HR 2.18, P = 0.009), higher AFP level (HR 1.02, per 10 ng/ml, P = 0.001), and higher DCP level (HR 1.01, per 10 mAU/ml, P = 0.001) as independent risk factors. Conclusions: These results indicated that MS is an independent risk factor of HCC recurrence after curative treatment in non-B non-C chronic liver disease patients.Family History Does Not Affect Survival from Hepatocellular CarcinomaNalani Grace 1 , Linda Wong 2 1 John A. Burns School of Medicine, 651 Ilalo Street, MEB 3rd Floor, 2 Hawaii Medical Center -East, 2226 Liliha Street, Suite 402Background: A family history of hepatocellular cancer (HCC) in a first-degree relative has been shown to be a risk factor for development of HCC, especially in Asian countries related to hepatitis B. Little is known if a family history of HCC affects survival. Aim: To compare HCC patients with a family history of HCC (FH+) to HCC patients without a family history (FH-). Methods: In a prospectively-collected database of 581 HCC patients(1993- 2009), 47 patients had a family history of HCC. Tumor characteristics, liver function, treatment, and survival were compared between FH+ and FH-. Results: In FH+, 19 had a sibling, 19 had a parent, and 1 had both with HCC. Eight patients had second-degree relatives and 3 had more than one relative with HCC. FH+ were more likely to be female, non-diabetics, hepatitis B+, and have higher albumin (all p \ 0.05). FH+ were as likely to be screened for HCC and the treatments did not differ. Median survival in FH+ was 1322 days (95%CI 569-2074 days) compared to FH-at 643 days and was not quite significant (p = 0.051). Cox regression showed that tumor size, MELD score, and albumin were the best predictors of survival. The presence of a family history of HCC did not affect survival. Conclusions: Only 8% of HCC is familial-related and the association is likely related to hepatitis B transmission. HCC is associated with poor survival among Asians in Asia. The survival of HCC among different ethnic group (Asians, Hispanic, African-Americans, and Caucasians) and within Asians in California was analyzed. In this study, the role of SES in the survival of racial disparity in HCC was investigated. Methods: Retrospective analysis(1995)(1996)(1997)(1998)(1999)(2000)(2001)(2002)(2003)(2004)(2005)(2006) of HCC patients from the California Cancer Registry (CCR) was performed. Univariate analyses of overall survival (OS) were conducted using the Kaplan-Meier method. Multivariate survival analyses were performed using Cox proportional hazards ratios (HRs). Results: 7392 HCC patients were analyzed. Male to female ratio is about 3:1. African-American (AA) patients were found to have higher proportion of advanced stage of disease, poorly differentiated status, fewer surgeries, fewer married status and Low SES. Among Asian-Americans, Filipinos were found to have higher proportion of advanced stage of disease, well and moderately differentiated status, fewer surgeries, and Low SES. Incremental improvements in SES quintile correlated with statistically significant decreases in the hazards ratios for death. In multivariate analysis, AA had unfavorable prognosis when compared to the rest of ethnicities; Filipinos had unfavorable prognosis when compared to the rest of Asian Americans (Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Vietnamese). Conclusion: Concurrent chemoradiation therapy didn't showed benefits to overall survival time, time to progression and tumor response.Background and aim: Impaired liver function with pharmacokinetics must be taken into consideration in the clinical study of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) patients. Methods: Patients were stratified based on the liver function, from no cirrhosis to Child-Pugh class B in phase I, and the effectiveness of TSU-68 were evaluated in phase II at the dose determined in phase I. Radiofrequency Ablation Combined with Hypertonic Saline: An Ex Vivo Study in Bovine Liver Paolo Villareal 1 , Stephen Wong 1 , Arl Ann Mendoza-Manzo 1 , Esperanza Grace Santi 1 , Redigo Aguilar 1 , Hendra Nurjadin 1 1 University of Santo Tomas Hospital, Espana, Manila, Philippines Background: Previous studies show that injection of hypertonic saline (26% NaCl) during radiofrequency ablation (RFA) results in larger coagulation volumes compared to RFA alone. Injecting hypertonic saline at a distance from the RFA electrode may further increase coagulation volume. Objective: To determine the effects of hypertonic saline injected beside or at a distance from the RFA electrode on coagulation diameter and volume after RFA. Methods: A Cooltip RFA electrode with 3 cm tip was used in freshly excised bovine livers. The experiment was divided into five groups with three repetitions each: (A) RFA alone; RFA with 33 mL (B) and 16.5 ml (C) hypertonic saline injected 15 mm away from the electrode; RFA with 33 mL (D) and 16.5 ml (E) hypertonic saline injected immediately beside the electrode. The maximum diameter and volume of coagulation, and sphericity ratios were compared using one-way ANOVA. Results: There were no differences in baseline impedance, and baseline and final tissue temperatures between the five groups (p [ 0.05). Despite a drop of 15.2 ± 7 Ohms in impedance after hypertonic saline injection, there were no differences in maximum coagulation diameters (A = 3.93 ± 0.49 cm vs. B = 3.53 ± 0.15 cm vs. C = 3.13 ± 0.15 cm vs. D = 3.83 ± 0.65 cm vs. E = 3.27 ± 0.49 cm; p = 0.19) and volumes (A = 33.14 ± 7.19 cm 3 vs. B = 22.87 ± 1.52 cm 3 vs. C = 18.99 ± 3.29 cm 3 vs. D = 25.41 ± 4.81 cm 3 vs. E = 22.55 ± 7.33 cm 3 ; p = 0.074). Sphericity ratios were less than 1 in all groups (p = 0.373), indicating slightly elongated coagulation. Conclusion: Although a decrease in impedance due to hypertonic saline may allow increased energy deposition, there was no advantage of combining hypertonic saline injection compared to RFA alone in bovine livers. A Case of Complete Response after Transaterial Chemoembolization and Radiotherapy for Portal Vein Malignant Thrombus in Patient with Unresectable Hepatocellular Carcinoma Nam Hwan Park 1 , Kwan Woo Nam 1 , Hee Jung Lee 1 , Sun Chang Hong 1 , Hee Seok Moon 1 , Eaum Seok Lee 1 , Seok Hyun Kim 1 , Byung Seok Lee 1 , Heon Young Lee 1 1 Chungnam National University School of Medicine, Daejeon, Korea Background: Radiation therapy (RT) is one of treatment choice for the patients who had unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and was unresponsive to the local ablation therapy or transarterial chemoembolization (TACE). RT is relatively safe, even if there is malignant thrombus in portal vein. We experienced a patient who had complete response after combined TACE and 3dimensional conformal radiotherapy (3D-CRT) for portal vein malignant thrombus in unresectable HCC. Method: A 49-years-old male patient who was diagnosed as multiple hepatic cellular carcinoma. He had underlying chronic hepatitis B related cirrhosis and liver function was Child-Pugh Class A. Its largest size was 9.1 cm and stage was III, T3N0M0. Malignant thrombosis was found at the left portal vein. He received two times TACE and radiation therapy in sequential order. Chemoembolization procedure was performed using lipiodol 18 cc and adriamycin 50 mg. A daily radiation dose was 180 cGy/day, and it was administered at 5 fractions a week, to deliver a total dose was 4,500 cGy. Result: Three months later, hepatoma presented marginal recurrence without thrombosis on the abdominal computer tomography. So, third TACE was done. Up to now, he is alive without any evidence of recurrence during 16 months. There was not any radiation induced toxicity. TABREF315.text: Aim of the study was to compare laparoscopic and open liver resection for patients with malignant hepatic tumors. Methods: Studies comparing laparoscopic and open liver resection published between 2002 and 2009 were included using the Medline search. Endpoints were: operative blood loss, operative time, hospital stay, postoperative complications. Results: Six nonrandomized pair-matched studies were identified. They comprised totally 677 patients of which 409 (60,4%) had laparoscopic procedure and 268 (39,6%) had open surgery. Operative blood loss was estimated in five studies where in all but one study it was significantly reduced in laparoscopic group (mean blood loss = 135 ml vs. 348 ml in open group; p \ 0.05). Operative time was assessed in five studies where in three of them it was significantly longer in laparoscopic group (mean time = 173 vs. 135 min in open group; p \ 0.05). Other two studies failed to show any statistical difference. Hospital stay was assessed in four studies, where in all of them it was significantly shorter in laparoscopic group (mean stay = 6.45 vs. 9 days in open group; p \ 0.05). Postoperative complications were assessed in only two studies where they were significantly more often seen in open group (mean rate = 37.4 vs. 9.3% in laparoscopic group; p \ 0.05).Conclusions: According to analyzed studies laparoscopic hepatectomy is at least as safe as open surgery. TABREF318.text: PP782Recent Improvement of Outcome of Hepatic Resection for Hepatocellular Carcinoma Woo Young Shin 1 , Kyung-Suk Suh 1 , Teahoon Kim 1 , Young-min Jeon 1 , Nam-joon Yi 1 , Kuhn Uk Lee1  1 Seoul National University Department of Surgery, Seoul Korea    Introduction: Hepatic resection for hepatocellular carcinoma is old standard treatment. Recently surgical skill, surgical instrument, perioperative management and diagnostic tools developed and surgical outcome also improved. Hence, we analyzed recent outcome of hepatic resection for HCC and investigated the prognostic factors relating to this. Methods: Between January 2001 and December 2006, 399 patients who underwent hepatic resection were retrospectively reviewed. Mean age was 53.8 year (17-81). There were 329 (82.5%) men and 70 (17.5%) women. Among these, 13 palliative cases were excluded. Median follow-up duration was 28 months (0.2-96.1). The chronological comparison was based on 2003. Results: Overall 5-year survival and disease-free survival rate were 59.4 and 33.5% respectively. According to chronology, 3-year survival rate, 3-year survival rate before and after 2003 were 65.7 and 78.8% respectively (P = 0.002). In-hospital mortality (3-month) and major morbidities after 2003 were significantly lower than before 2003 (4.8 vs. 0.4%, P = 0.004; 15.9 vs 5.4%, P \ 0.001). On multivariate analysis, preoperative AFP (HR = 1.66, P = 0.021), tumor size (HR = 2.49, P \ 0.001), microvascular invasion (HR = 2.94, P \ 0.001), and intraoperative transfusion (HR = 2.45, P = 0.003) were independent prognostic factors for survival. According to subgroup analysis using tumor size B5 cm and microvascular invasion (mvi), survival rate of group with B5 cm & mvi(-),[5 cm & mvi(-), B5 cm & mvi(+), and[5 cm & mvi(+)  were 79.0, 59.0, 60.9, and 28.1% respectively (P \ 0.001), 5-disease-free survival rate of each group were 54.0, 34.4, 20.1, and 9.5% respectively (P \ 0.001). Especially, 5-year survival rate of BCLC A1 patients with tumor size B5 cm was 83.7%. Conclusion: Recently the rate of operative mortality and morbidity is getting lower. Hepatic resection should be considered as the treatment of choice in patients with small HCC and good liver function.

TABREF320.text: Hepatocellular Carcinoma with Bile Duct Invasion: Survival and Prognostic Factors in Inoperable Cases Hwi Young Kim 1 , Su Jong Yu 1 , Sang Youn Hwang 1 , Joon Suk Kim 1 , Goh Eun Chung 1 , Jeong-Hoon Lee 1 , Yoon Jun Kim 1 , Jung-Hwan Yoon 1 , Hyo-Suk Lee 1 1 Department of Internal Medicine and Liver Research Institute, Seoul National University College of Medicine, 28 Yungun Dong, Chongno Gu, 110-744, Seoul, KoreaBackground: Curative surgical resection (SR) has been an established treatment for patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with bile duct invasion whenever operable. However, clinical course or treatment strategy for inoperable cases remains to be elucidated. The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of nonsurgical treatment option as well as relevant factors in survival in such cases. Methods: Inclusion criteria were consecutive patients who were diagnosed as HCC with bile duct invasion and were not eligible for SR, between January 2005 and December 2008 at a single tertiary medical center in Korea. Survival analyses were performed to compare various clinical parameters and to evaluate prognostic factors. Results: Except for six patients who undertook SR, a total of 66 patients were included (mean age, 56.3 years; male, 80.3%). Hyperbilirubinemia was observed in 62% of patients at the time of diagnosis (mean, 5.0 ± 7.25 mg/dL). During the observation period (median, 34.1; range, 10.4-57.4 months), 50 patients died (median survival, 5.9 months; 95% C.I., 3.6-8.2 months). Independent predictors for overall survival included UICC T stage, tumor morphology (nodular vs. diffuse), and initial treatment modality (transarterial chemoembolization (TACE) vs. systemic therapy) in the multivariate analyses. Other factors such as morphologic classification (Ueda) of bile duct invasion, UICC N or M stage and serum a-fetoprotein level failed to affect the OS significantly. Considering patients with Child-Pugh class A or B, patients treated with TACE showed significantly longer survival than those who did not receive TACE (median OS, 9.3 months vs. 1.9 months, respectively; P \ 0.0001). back_matter.text: Background: Hypoxia may activate survival signals in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cells. We have previously shown that hexokinase II (HK II) is actively participating in HCC cell survival, especially in a hypoxic environment, and that HK II inhibitor can induce apoptosis by activating mitochondrial signals. Hypoxia may also activate endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress, which is counteracted by unfolded protein response such as protein disulfide isomerase (PDI) activation. Since HK II inhibitor may as well activate pro-apoptotic JNK, and ER stress can also lead to JNK activation,we hypothesized that PDI inhibition may potentiate HK II inhibitor-induced JNK activation and apoptosis by increasing ER stress in hypoxic HCC cells. Methods: Huh-7 cells were used in this study. Cells were treated with bacitracin,a PDI inhibitor, and/or 3-bromopyruvate(3-BP),a HK II inhibitor. Cellular apoptosis was analyzed by MPT assay, and apoptotic and kinase signaling pathways were explored by immunoblot analysis. Results: The expression of PDI was increased in HCC cells cultured in hypoxia as compared to normoxic cells. Bacitracin treatment alone did not induce HCC cell death. While 3-BP treatment alone did not induce ER stress in hypoxic HCC cells, 3-BP treatment was able to induce ER stress in the presence of bacitracin. Accordingly, a strong 3-BP-induced JNK activation was observed Aim: Prognosis of advanced cholangiocellular carcinoma is extremely poor. We reported the effectiveness of Combination Therapy of 5-Fluorouracil and Interferon-Alpha for Advanced hepatocellular carcinoma (S Obi et al. Cancer 2006). This study aimed for pilot study of combination therapy of 5-fluorouracil and interferon for advanced cholangiocellular carcinoma. Method: Fifteen patients with cholangiocellular carcinoma received peginterferon (90 ng, subcutaneous injection on weekly) and 5-Fluorouracil (500 mg into hepatic artery on Days 1-5 of the first and second week of each 4-week cycle). The therapy was either terminated at the end of the first cycle in cases with progressive disease, or continued when responses to treatment were evaluated by Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group criteria. Result: Four (27%) patients showed partial response (PR) and complete remission (CR) was not observed. Two patients (23%) showed stable disease (SD). The median survival time was 9.0 months. Hsp27 Phosphorylation can Enhance Radioresistance of Hepatocarcinoma Cells by Stimulating Akt Activation Alexander Kabakov 1 , Yulia Makarova 1 , Vladimir Kudryavtsev 1 1 Medical Radiology Research Center, 4 Korolev Street, Obninsk, 249036, Russia Background/Aims: The 27 kDa heat shock protein (Hsp27) is a cytoprotective chaperone whose constitutive expression is increased in many human tumors and associated with poor prognosis. Hsp27 is involved in radioprotective responses of tumor cells, while machinery of such Hsp27-involving radioprotection is not quite unraveled. The present study was aimed at elucidation of a role of Hsp27 phosphorylation in the phenomenon of irradiation-responsive Akt activation (phosphorylation) that contributes to the hepatocarcinoma cell radioresistance. Methods: Human hepatocarcinoma cells (HepG2 and HCCLM3 lines) were exposed to gamma-radiation at clinically relevant doses (3-6 Gy). The site-specific phosphorylation of Hsp27 and Akt or Hsp27-Akt interaction was determined by immunoblotting or immunoprecipitation (IP), respectively. The post-irradiation cell death and survival were assessed in TUNEL or annexin V-staining and clonogenic assays. Transient transfection with dominant negative or constitutively activated Akt was used to manipulate the Akt activity in the cells. Results: It was found that human hepatocarcinoma cells, constitutively expressing high Hsp27 levels, respond to gamma-radiation exposure by Hsp27 phosphorylation and subsequent Akt phosphorylation (activation); later, some cell fractions entered apoptosis. Down-regulation of Hsp27 with RNAi as well as inhibition of the Hsp27 phosphorylation with SB203580 or dominant-negative MAPKAP kinase-2 suppressed the Akt activation and enhanced apoptosis. Effects of (co-)transfection with mutant Hsp27 and/or Akt also suggest implication of the Hsp27 phosphorylation in catalyzing the radioprotective Akt activation in the irradiated tumor cells. IP from the cell lysates revealed Hsp27-,Akt-containing complexes which dissociate when Hsp27 is phosphorylated following irradiation. Conclusion: These findings characterize the Hsp27 phosphorylation as an important event in the radioprotective response of hepatocarcinoma cells. Consequently, pharmacological inhibition of the Hsp27 phosphorylation in human hepatocarcinomas may sensitize them to radiotherapy.
